title: Free-to-use / GPL Fonts and software
content:
Hi everyone,

First post and so on - but I’ve been lurking around as a guest for a little while now. I love the site, the design and the ideas discussed - hope I can add something to the discussion where appropriate, but warning now, self taught know-nothing in most respects...

So - the question - I was wondering if there was a respectable open source or free-to-use (for non-commercial applications even) win32 or OSX program that people are using to build fonts with?

What kind of programs are used to make fonts for linux distributions too? Is there a gpl tool which is used... or are people using commercial applications to build things which are then donated to the distirbutions..?

Thanking kindly!

Dan
author: dazld

comments.content:
The most established such tool is FontForge. It started out as something of a Fontographer clone for Type1 fonts only, but has grown considerable sophistication for TT and OpenType as well.

My own fonts, including Inconsolata, are developed using my [Spiro](http://web.archive.org/web/20091107124024/http:/levien.com/spiro/) tools. The underlying math is quite sophisticated, but the polish and packaging to make it a smooth, easy-to-use app is absolutely not there yet. I will continue to chip at the code in support of those goals, but I expect progress to be very slow unless considerable new energy comes into the project from other collaborators.

See also Dave Crossland’s talk at [LGM](http://web.archive.org/web/20091107124024/http:/www.libregraphicsmeeting.org/2007/program.html) (audio and video links of the presentation inside that link). There is a bit of information about less mainstream tools on the [OFLib Wiki](http://web.archive.org/web/20091107124024/http:/openfontlibrary.org/wiki/index.php/Tools) as well.

Best of luck!

FontForge [http://fontforge.sourceforge.net/](http://web.archive.org/web/20091107124024/http:/fontforge.sourceforge.net/) (that what Raph mentioned) is a tool for developing fonts, free to use and modify under “essentially the revised BSD license”. It is a UNIX type of program, but has builds that work under X11 on MacOSX and Cygwin on Windows.

Also, Adobe, Microsoft, and Apple all have font development utilities they distribute free of charge from their respective web sites. They perform very important technical functions but do not handle design. I haven’t figured out much about them but I’m sure other typophiles are more familiar with them.

Dazld,

you can find some links to font development software (both commercial and free) on my page:

[http://www.font.org/software/](http://web.archive.org/web/20091107124024/http:/www.font.org/software/ "http://www.font.org/software/")

Regards,  
Adam
